entry.et: Middle English, real, relating to things (in law), from Anglo-French, from Medieval Latin & Late Latin; Medieval Latin realis relating to things (in law), from Late Latin, real, from Latin res thing, fact; akin to Sanskrit rayi property

def.dt: :of or relating to fixed, permanent, or immovable things (as lands or tenements)
:not artificial, fraudulent, or illusory :genuine real gold
:being precisely what the name implies a real professional
:occurring or existing in actuality saw a real live celebrity a story of real life
:of or relating to practical or everyday concerns or activities left school to live in the real world
:existing as a physical entity and having properties that deviate from an ideal, law, or standard a real gas compare ideal 3b
:having objective independent existence unable to believe that what he saw was real
:fundamental essential
:belonging to or having elements or components that belong to the set of real numbers the real roots of an equation a real matrix
:concerned with or containing real numbers real analysis
:real-valued real variable
:measured by purchasing power real income real dollars
:complete utter a real fiasco
:capable of being detected compare virtual 3
:in earnest :seriously fighting for real
:genuine couldn't believe the threats were for real
:genuinely good or capable of success (as in competition) not yet sure if this team is for real
:a real thing
:a mathematically real quantity
:very he was real cool H. M. McLuhan

entry.pt: Most handbooks consider the adverb real to be informal and more suitable to speech than writing. Our evidence shows these observations to be true in the main, but real is becoming more common in writing of an informal, conversational style. It is used as an intensifier only and is not interchangeable with really except in that use.

entry.et: Spanish, from real royal, from Latin regalis royal

def.dt: :a former monetary unit and coin of Spain and its possessions

entry.et: Portuguese, from real royal, from Latin regalis

def.dt: :a former monetary unit and coin of Portugal

entry.et: Arabic riyāl, from Spanish real real

def.dt: :property in buildings and land
:space capacity desktop real estate the limited real estate on hard drives Leonard Wiener
:a point at which rays (as of light) converge or from which they diverge
